Title: Haydn Symphony No 44 in E minor ‚ÄûTrauersinfonie‚Äú Yannick N√©zet--Seguin
Description:
Joseph Haydn 
Sinfonie e-Moll Hoboken-Verzeichnis I:44, ‚ÄûTrauersinfonie‚Äú
Symphony No 44 in E minor, "Mourning"
Yannick N√©zet--Seguin COE
1. Allegro con brio, 4/4 0:12
2. Menuetto: Allegretto, 3/4 6:45
3. Adagio, 2/4 12:20
4. Finale: Presto, 2/2 19:55
The Symphony No. 44 in E minor, Hoboken 1/44, was completed in 1772 by Joseph Haydn. It is popularly known as Trauer (English: Mourning). Late in life, Haydn asked for the slow movement of this symphony to be played at his funeral.

Title: Lang Lang, Chick Corea, Maxim Lando play Gershwin‚Äôs Rhapsody In Blue conducted by Y. N√©zet-S√©guin
Description:
Lang Lang, Chick Corea, and Maxim Lando play George Gershwin‚Äôs Rhapsody In Blue with Yannick N√©zet-S√©guin conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra (no video)

Link to whole concert (includes interviews with Chick and Lang Lang): https://www.wqxr.org/story/carnegie-hall-opens-season-music-broadcast-gershwin-and-bernstein/

Concert Program:

This Summer, WQXR lets you relive highlights from our past season at Carnegie Hall. On Wednesday Oct. 4, WQXR broadcast the Carnegie Hall season opener with the music of Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue and Bernstein's symphonic arrangements of his music for On the Waterfront and West Side Story. Featured soloists are pianists Lang Lang and Chick Corea, as well as 14-year-old Maxim Lando. The young pianist joined in on a two-piano arrangement of Rhapsody. Specifically, he played the left-hand part for Lang Lang, who was battling inflammation in his left arm. 

Jeff Spurgeon and John Schaefer were the evening's hosts. Share your thoughts during the broadcast using #CHLive.

Listen to the archive of the concert above.

Program:

Leonard Bernstein: On the Waterfront Symphonic Suite
George Gershwin: Rhapsody in Blue
Leonard Bernstein: Symphonic Dances from West Side Story

The Philadelphia Orchestra
Yannick N√©zet-S√©guin, Music Director and Conductor
Lang Lang, Piano
Chick Corea, Piano
Maxim Lando, Piano

I don‚Äôt own the rights to this content. I only put this up because I was looking for a recording of the 2 legends, Lang Lang and Chick Corea (as well as the rising star Maxim Lando) playing together and it took a little digging to actually find it so I thought I‚Äôd put it on YouTube to make it more accessible! Huge thanks to WQXR for recording, documenting, and making this performance public for free!

Title: Liszt, Piano Concerto No. 1
Description:
Daniil Trifonov @daniiltrifonov 
Philadelphia Orchestra @ThePhiladelphiaOrchestra / Yannick N√©zet-S√©guin - 
Franz Liszt: Piano Concerto No. 1 in E-flat Major, S. 124 (1849)  

00:00 Allegro maestoso 
06:00 Quasi adagio 
11:19 Allegretto vivace - Allegro animato 
15:26 Allegro marziale animato 

19:23 Applause 

21:41 [Encore] Johann Sebastian Bach: Cantata BWV147 'Herz und Mund und Tat und Leben,' Jesu, Joy of Man‚Äôs Desiring (Transcr. Myra Hess for Piano) 

25:17 Applause 

26:57 Daniil testing the piano before his performance  
27:20 Yannick N√©zet-S√©guin talks about Daniil 

Isaac Stern Auditorium / Ronald O. Perelman Stage at Carnegie Hall, New York, USA 
Sep. 29, 2022 
Carnegie Hall's Opening Night of the 132nd Season 
@carnegiehall 

Live broadcast on WQXR 
(www.wqxr.org/story/opening-night-gala-2022-2023-season/?tab=summary) 

Oussama Zahr's review: 

"[...] Trifonov‚Äôs passagework had a hard glare, and he lined up chords neatly like punctuation marks. Liszt threw down a gauntlet with 19 straight bars of trills in a piece already rife with difficulty, and Trifonov kept it sparking and spinning. It‚Äôs a miracle he has any fingerprints left. His scherzo had a wonderfully light air about it. [...]" 

üîó www.nytimes.com/2022/09/30/arts/music/philadelphia-orchestra-carnegie-hall-review.html  

Rick Perdian‚Äôs review:

"[...] But if one is to lose the thread, who better to lose it with than the poetic young Russian pianist, with his massive fortes, dreamy pianissimos and stretchy rubato? In the spirit of a piece the composer himself called a fantasy, Trifonov‚Äôs imaginative playing sustained interest throughout, and seemed to inspire the orchestra as well. [...]" 

üîóseenandheard-international.com/2022/10/the-philadelphia-orchestra-and-daniil-trifonov-shine-in-carnegie-halls-season-opener/

David Wright‚Äôs review:

"[...] Pianist Daniil Trifonov was the embodiment of a Romantic artist with flowing hair and open-collared shirt. At times he leapt off the piano bench as he dispatched the concerto‚Äôs formidable technical challenges with passion and virtuosity. It was just as exhilarating to watch him play the thundering octaves, intricate ornamentations and sweeping arpeggios. [...]" 

üîó newyorkclassicalreview.com/2022/09/philadelphians-open-carnegie-season-in-high-yannick-mode-with-brash-ravel-fantastic-liszt

Title: Mahler - Symphonie Nr. 1 | Yannick N√©zet-S√©guin | BRSO
Description:
Gustav Mahlers Symphonie Nr. 1 in D-Dur, gespielt vom Symphonieorchester des Bayerischen Rundfunks unter der Leitung von Yannick N√©zet-S√©guin. Live aufgenommen im Jahr 2014. Eine Produktion von BR-KLASSIK.

Gustav Mahler's Symphony No. 1 in D major, performed by the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Yannick N√©zet-S√©guin. Recorded live in 2014. A production of BR-KLASSIK.

Gustav Mahler - Symphonie Nr. 1 in D-Dur

I. Langsam. Schleppend. Wie ein Naturlaut ‚Äì Im Anfang sehr gem√§chlich
II. Kr√§ftig bewegt, doch nicht zu schnell
III. Feierlich und gemessen, ohne zu schleppen
IV. St√ºrmisch bewegt

Die Symphonie Nr. 1 von Gustav Mahler stie√ü anfangs auf sehr kritische Ohren. Zu grell und rei√üerisch waren die ironischen, karikierenden musikalischen Effekte, zu fremd die Gegens√§tze von Triumph und Depression. Da half auch das als Erl√§uterung gedachte, in den folgenden Auff√ºhrungen beigelegte Programm Mahlers nicht. Er gab dabei seiner Symphonie den Namen "Titan", in Anlehnung an Jean Pauls Roman. Doch das Publikum verstand diese sehr pittoresken Hinweise zu w√∂rtlich, worauf Mahler davon schnell wieder Abstand nahm. Heute geh√∂rt Mahlers Erste zu den monumentalsten und beliebtesten Werken in den Konzerts√§len weltweit. 
Das Symphonieorchester des Bayerischen Rundfunks f√ºhrte Gustav Mahlers Symphonie Nr. 1 am 27. Juni 2014 im M√ºnchner Herkulessaal auf. Die Leitung hatte der kanadische Dirigent Yannick N√©zet-S√©guin.

Symphonieorchester des Bayerischen Rundfunks
Dirigent: Yannick N√©zet-S√©guin

Title: The Philadelphia Orchestra: BeethovenNOW: Symphonies 5 & 6

As The Philadelphia Orchestra suspended concerts and events in response to COVID-19, on Thursday, March 12 this special performance to an empty Verizon Hall was streamed live to audiences throughout the Philadelphia region and around the world.
